title: Habakkuk Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Habakkuk chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Habakkuk Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Habakkuk Chapter 3.

questions.question: Who is the prayer in Habakkuk 3:1 attributed to?
options: Habakkuk the prophet
Moses
David
Isaiah
questions.correctAnswer: Habakkuk the prophet
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:1 states that it is a prayer of Habakkuk the prophet.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 3:2, what does the prophet ask the LORD to revive?
options: His work
The temple
The city
The people
questions.correctAnswer: His work
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:2 says, 'O LORD, revive thy work in the midst of the years.'

questions.question: From which places did God come according to Habakkuk 3:3?
options: Teman and mount Paran
Jerusalem and Zion
Egypt and Babylon
Sinai and Horeb
questions.correctAnswer: Teman and mount Paran
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:3 states, 'God came from Teman, and the Holy One from mount Paran.'

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 3:4, what was coming out of God's hand?
options: Horns
Fire
Water
Light
questions.correctAnswer: Horns
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:4 mentions, 'he had horns coming out of his hand.'

questions.question: What went before God as described in Habakkuk 3:5?
options: The pestilence
The wind
The sun
The fire
questions.correctAnswer: The pestilence
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:5 says, 'Before him went the pestilence.'

questions.question: In Habakkuk 3:6, what did the everlasting mountains do?
options: Were scattered
Stood firm
Were covered in snow
Were silent
questions.correctAnswer: Were scattered
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:6 states, 'the everlasting mountains were scattered.'

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 3:7 describes the tents of Cushan as being in affliction.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:7 says, 'I saw the tents of Cushan in affliction.'

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 3:8, what did the LORD ride upon?
options: Horses and chariots of salvation
A cloud
A lion
A chariot of fire
questions.correctAnswer: Horses and chariots of salvation
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:8 states, 'that thou didst ride upon thine horses and thy chariots of salvation.'

questions.question: What did God cleave the earth with according to Habakkuk 3:9?
options: Rivers
Fire
Wind
Mountains
questions.correctAnswer: Rivers
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:9 says, 'Thou didst cleave the earth with rivers.'

questions.question: In Habakkuk 3:11, what stood still in their habitation?
options: The sun and moon
The stars
The mountains
The sea
questions.correctAnswer: The sun and moon
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:11 states, 'The sun and moon stood still in their habitation.'

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 3:12 describes the LORD threshing the heathen in anger.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:12 says, 'Thou didst thresh the heathen in anger.'

questions.question: Who did the LORD go forth for according to Habakkuk 3:13?
options: His people and his anointed
The heathen
The kings
The priests
questions.correctAnswer: His people and his anointed
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:13 states, 'Thou wentest forth for the salvation of thy people, even for salvation with thine anointed.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Habakkuk 3:17: 'Although the fig tree shall not ______.'
options: blossom
wither
grow
fall
questions.correctAnswer: blossom
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:17 says, 'Although the fig tree shall not blossom.'

questions.question: What does the prophet say he will do in the LORD in Habakkuk 3:18?
options: Rejoice and joy
Weep and mourn
Flee and hide
Sing and dance
questions.correctAnswer: Rejoice and joy
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:18 says, 'Yet I will rejoice in the LORD, I will joy in the God of my salvation.'

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 3:19 describes the LORD giving strength and making feet like hinds' feet.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:19 states, 'The LORD God is my strength, and he will make my feet like hinds' feet.'

medium.title: Habakkuk Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Habakkuk Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is experiencing fear after hearing troubling news. Based on Habakkuk 3:2, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during fearful times?
options: Trust that the Lord will revive His work and remember mercy even in wrath
Ignore the fear and rely solely on your own strength
Seek earthly solutions first before praying
Avoid thinking about God's judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that the Lord will revive His work and remember mercy even in wrath
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:2 teaches us to trust God to revive His work and to remember mercy amid His wrath, offering assurance in fearful times. This encourages faith and hope rather than despair.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 3:3-4 depict God's power and glory, and what practical lesson does this teach about relying on God's strength in daily challenges?
options: God's glory covers the heavens and His brightness is like light, showing we can depend on His overwhelming power
God is distant and uninvolved in earthly matters
God’s power is hidden and uncertain
God’s glory is only for special people
questions.correctAnswer: God's glory covers the heavens and His brightness is like light, showing we can depend on His overwhelming power
questions.explanation: Verses 3-4 describe God's glory covering the heavens and brightness like light, indicating His powerful presence. This encourages believers to rely on God's strength in trials and to trust His sovereign power.

questions.question: What does Habakkuk 3:5-6 teach us about God's control over nations and nature, and how can this help believers maintain humility and trust in Him?
options: God measures the earth and drives nations apart, showing His ultimate authority over history
Nations control their own fate without God's influence
Mountains and hills are stronger than God
God only controls small details, not big events
questions.correctAnswer: God measures the earth and drives nations apart, showing His ultimate authority over history
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 reveal God's sovereign control over nations and nature, which teaches believers humility and trust that God directs history and earthly events according to His purposes.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with anger toward others. According to Habakkuk 3:12-13, what biblical truth about God's righteous anger and salvation could encourage them to respond with faith?
options: God’s indignation is against the wicked, but He also brings salvation for His anointed people
God is always angry and punishes all people equally
God’s anger is unpredictable and unfair
Salvation is only for those who never sin
questions.correctAnswer: God’s indignation is against the wicked, but He also brings salvation for His anointed people
questions.explanation: Verses 12-13 describe God’s righteous anger against the wicked and His salvation for His people, encouraging believers to trust God’s justice and salvation even amid trials.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 3:16-18 teach us to respond to hardship and loss with faith and joy in God?
options: Even if all earthly blessings fail, we can rejoice and find strength in God
We should despair when trials come
Only material blessings prove God’s favor
Faith is not important during suffering
questions.correctAnswer: Even if all earthly blessings fail, we can rejoice and find strength in God
questions.explanation: Verses 16-18 emphasize rejoicing in the Lord despite loss or hardship, showing that true joy and strength come from God, not circumstances.

questions.question: A friend is feeling weak and unable to face challenges. Based on Habakkuk 3:19, what encouragement about God's strength and guidance can you share?
options: God is our strength and will enable us to walk securely on difficult paths
We must rely only on our own abilities
God abandons us in hard times
We should avoid challenges altogether
questions.correctAnswer: God is our strength and will enable us to walk securely on difficult paths
questions.explanation: Verse 19 assures believers that God is their strength and will give them agility and confidence to overcome difficult situations, encouraging perseverance and trust.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 3:8 teach us about God's power over natural forces and His role as Savior, and what practical application does this have for our trust in Him?
options: God commands even rivers and seas, showing He is mighty to save
Nature is beyond God's control
God is limited to spiritual matters only
God acts only through human effort
questions.correctAnswer: God commands even rivers and seas, showing He is mighty to save
questions.explanation: Verse 8 illustrates God's authority over powerful natural elements, reinforcing that He is mighty to save, which encourages believers to trust His saving power in all circumstances.

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 3:11 states that the sun and moon stood still because of the light of God's arrows and the shining of His spear.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:11 describes the sun and moon standing still at the light of God's arrows and shining spear, symbolizing His supernatural power and control over creation.

questions.question: What does Habakkuk 3:14 teach about God's judgment on the wicked, and how should this truth influence a believer's attitude toward justice and forgiveness?
options: God's judgment is powerful and swift against the wicked, reminding believers to trust His justice while practicing forgiveness
Believers should take revenge themselves
God ignores the wicked
Justice is not important for Christians
questions.correctAnswer: God's judgment is powerful and swift against the wicked, reminding believers to trust His justice while practicing forgiveness
questions.explanation: Verse 14 shows God's decisive judgment on evil, teaching believers to trust God's justice rather than seeking personal vengeance, and to maintain a forgiving heart.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Habakkuk 3:18 says, 'Yet I will rejoice in the _______, I will joy in the God of my salvation.'
options: LORD
world
king
people
questions.correctAnswer: LORD
questions.explanation: The verse expresses rejoicing in the LORD despite difficulties, highlighting faith and gratitude toward God as the source of true joy (Habakkuk 3:18).

questions.question: In Habakkuk 3:1, the chapter begins as a prayer 'upon Shigionoth.' How does this introduction encourage believers about the role of prayer and worship in facing life's challenges?
options: Prayer and worship are vital spiritual disciplines for seeking God's help and guidance
Prayer is unnecessary during trials
Worship should be private and silent only
Only prophets can pray effectively
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer and worship are vital spiritual disciplines for seeking God's help and guidance
questions.explanation: Verse 1 shows Habakkuk beginning with a prayer, emphasizing the importance of approaching God in worship and petition during difficult times, encouraging believers to do likewise.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 3:9 describe God's faithfulness to His promises, and what practical lesson does this teach about obedience and trust?
options: God’s word and oaths are reliable, calling believers to obey and trust Him fully
God often changes His promises
Believers should only obey when convenient
Trust in God is optional
questions.correctAnswer: God’s word and oaths are reliable, calling believers to obey and trust Him fully
questions.explanation: Verse 9 highlights God’s faithful word and oaths, encouraging believers to have confidence in His promises and live obediently according to His revealed will.

questions.question: True or False: According to Habakkuk 3:16, the prophet’s body and spirit trembled at the voice of God, yet he sought to find rest in the day of trouble.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 16 describes Habakkuk trembling inwardly but seeking rest in God during trouble, demonstrating humility and trust amidst fear.

questions.question: Habakkuk 3:7 mentions the tents of Cushan in affliction and the curtains of Midian trembling. How does this imagery help believers understand God's power over human circumstances and encourage humility?
options: God’s presence causes even distant peoples and places to tremble, reminding us of His sovereignty over all
God only cares about Israel and ignores others
Human events happen randomly without God’s involvement
We should fear others more than God
questions.correctAnswer: God’s presence causes even distant peoples and places to tremble, reminding us of His sovereignty over all
questions.explanation: Verse 7 uses vivid imagery to show God's awe-inspiring power affecting nations, encouraging believers to trust God's control over all situations and maintain humility.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 3:15, which says God walked through the sea with horses and great waters, inspire believers regarding God's presence and help in overwhelming situations?
options: God actively intervenes in overwhelming situations to bring deliverance
God is distant during crises
Believers must face struggles alone
Natural disasters cannot be overcome
questions.correctAnswer: God actively intervenes in overwhelming situations to bring deliverance
questions.explanation: Verse 15 portrays God's mighty intervention through powerful imagery, assuring believers that God is present and able to save even in overwhelming circumstances.

hard.title: Habakkuk Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Habakkuk Chapter 3.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 3:3, from which locations does God come, and what is the significance of these places in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: Teman and mount Paran, representing the regions of Edom and the Sinai wilderness
Jerusalem and Mount Zion, symbolizing the center of Israel's worship
Babylon and Nineveh, representing the enemies of Israel
Egypt and Cush, symbolizing foreign lands under judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Teman and mount Paran, representing the regions of Edom and the Sinai wilderness
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:3 states that God came from Teman and mount Paran. Historically, Teman is associated with Edom, a nation south of Israel, and mount Paran is linked to the Sinai wilderness, highlighting God's majestic and transcendent arrival from distant, rugged regions.

questions.question: What literary device is most evident in Habakkuk 3:4's description of God's brightness and horns coming out of His hand?
options: Symbolism illustrating divine power and authority
Personification of natural elements
Allegory of Israel's restoration
Chiasmus reflecting God's justice
questions.correctAnswer: Symbolism illustrating divine power and authority
questions.explanation: The imagery of brightness like light and horns coming from God's hand in Habakkuk 3:4 employs symbolism to portray God's power and majesty, with horns often symbolizing strength in ancient Near Eastern iconography.

questions.question: Habakkuk 3:5 mentions pestilence and burning coals going forth at God's feet. This imagery foreshadows which Old Testament event?
options: The plagues in Egypt during the Exodus
The destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah
The flood in Noah’s time
The conquest of Jericho
questions.correctAnswer: The plagues in Egypt during the Exodus
questions.explanation: The pestilence and burning coals symbolize divine judgment reminiscent of the plagues in Egypt, indicating God's power to bring both destruction and salvation as seen in Exodus narratives.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'his ways are everlasting' in Habakkuk 3:6 reveal about God's nature in relation to the historical upheavals described?
options: God’s actions are eternal and sovereign beyond temporal chaos
God is indifferent to human affairs
God changes His plans frequently
God’s judgments are temporary
questions.correctAnswer: God’s actions are eternal and sovereign beyond temporal chaos
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:6 emphasizes that although nations and mountains may be shaken, God’s ways are eternal, underscoring His unchanging sovereignty amidst historical turmoil.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 3:7, the tents of Cushan are described as being in affliction. Which historical or cultural group does this likely refer to, and why is this significant?
options: Cushan refers to Cushites, located south of Israel, indicating widespread fear of divine judgment
Cushan refers to the Philistines, Israel’s coastal enemies
Cushan is symbolic of Babylonian exile
Cushan represents the Assyrian empire
questions.correctAnswer: Cushan refers to Cushites, located south of Israel, indicating widespread fear of divine judgment
questions.explanation: The tents of Cushan in affliction (Habakkuk 3:7) likely refer to Cushites, an ancient people south of Israel, showing that even distant nations tremble before God’s power.

questions.question: Habakkuk 3:8 asks if the LORD was displeased against the rivers and the sea, riding on horses and chariots of salvation. This imagery is an allusion to which biblical motif?
options: Divine warrior motif depicting God as victorious in battle
Creation narrative emphasizing water’s role
Covenant ceremony with Israel
Prophetic vision of peace and restoration
questions.correctAnswer: Divine warrior motif depicting God as victorious in battle
questions.explanation: The imagery of God riding horses and chariots in Habakkuk 3:8 reflects the divine warrior motif common in the Old Testament, portraying God as a mighty warrior conquering chaos and enemies.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'bow made quite naked' in Habakkuk 3:9, especially in relation to the 'oaths of the tribes'?
options: The bow symbolizes God's readiness to fulfill His covenant promises
The bow represents Israel's military failure
The bow is a metaphor for Israel's disobedience
The bow illustrates the futility of human effort
questions.correctAnswer: The bow symbolizes God's readiness to fulfill His covenant promises
questions.explanation: In Habakkuk 3:9, the naked bow connected to tribal oaths indicates God’s readiness to act decisively in keeping His covenant with Israel.

questions.question: Habakkuk 3:11 describes the sun and moon standing still at the light of God’s arrows. Which biblical event does this parallel, and what does this imply?
options: Joshua’s command for the sun to stand still (Joshua 10), implying divine intervention in battle
The creation account in Genesis 1, emphasizing order
The Exodus night of the Passover, highlighting judgment
The crossing of the Red Sea, illustrating salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Joshua’s command for the sun to stand still (Joshua 10), implying divine intervention in battle
questions.explanation: The imagery in Habakkuk 3:11 recalls Joshua 10 where the sun and moon stood still, symbolizing God’s power to control nature for His people’s deliverance.

questions.question: What is the authorial intent behind the vivid martial imagery in Habakkuk 3:12-14, describing threshing the heathen and striking the head of the wicked?
options: To portray God's judgment on Israel’s enemies and affirm His role as protector
To encourage Israel to wage war on their own
To depict human violence as the source of salvation
To criticize Israel’s leadership
questions.correctAnswer: To portray God's judgment on Israel’s enemies and affirm His role as protector
questions.explanation: The martial imagery in Habakkuk 3:12-14 emphasizes God’s active judgment against wicked nations, portraying Him as Israel’s divine warrior and protector.

questions.question: Habakkuk 3:15 describes God walking through the sea with horses through great waters. What Old Testament event does this recall, and what theological theme does it reinforce?
options: Crossing of the Red Sea, reinforcing God’s deliverance and sovereign control over chaos
Noah’s flood, emphasizing judgment by water
Jonah’s experience, symbolizing repentance
Elijah’s ascent, symbolizing divine presence
questions.correctAnswer: Crossing of the Red Sea, reinforcing God’s deliverance and sovereign control over chaos
questions.explanation: God walking through the sea with horses in Habakkuk 3:15 evokes the Exodus crossing of the Red Sea, highlighting God’s power to save His people and master chaotic waters.

questions.question: The trembling and rottenness entering Habakkuk’s bones in Habakkuk 3:16 can be interpreted as a typology of what New Testament experience?
options: The fear and awe before Christ’s judgment and glory
The joy of Pentecost
The peace of the Beatitudes
The resurrection hope
questions.correctAnswer: The fear and awe before Christ’s judgment and glory
questions.explanation: Habakkuk’s trembling in 3:16 typifies the deep reverence and fear believers experience in anticipation of Christ’s final judgment and divine glory.

questions.question: Despite the devastation described in Habakkuk 3:17, what is the prophet's response in 3:18, and how does this reflect a key biblical theme?
options: Rejoicing in the LORD, reflecting faith and trust amid adversity
Despair and hopelessness
Anger towards God
Indifference to circumstances
questions.correctAnswer: Rejoicing in the LORD, reflecting faith and trust amid adversity
questions.explanation: In Habakkuk 3:18, the prophet chooses joy in God despite calamity, exemplifying the biblical theme of trust and hope in God’s salvation regardless of external conditions.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the metaphor in Habakkuk 3:19, where God makes the prophet's feet like hinds' feet to walk upon high places?
options: It symbolizes divine strength and agility to overcome spiritual challenges
It represents physical exercise
It illustrates a call to retreat from difficulties
It denotes a literal mountain climb
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes divine strength and agility to overcome spiritual challenges
questions.explanation: The metaphor of hinds' feet in Habakkuk 3:19 highlights God's empowerment enabling the prophet to navigate difficult and elevated spiritual terrain with confidence and stability.

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 3:2 is a plea for God to recall mercy despite His wrath, indicating the prophet’s hope for divine compassion.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:2 explicitly asks God to remember mercy in the midst of wrath, showing the prophet’s desire for God’s compassionate intervention.

questions.question: Which literary structure is notably present in Habakkuk 3, particularly in the arrangement of divine actions and responses throughout the chapter?
options: A chiasm highlighting God’s judgments and deliverances
A linear historical narrative
A parable teaching moral lessons
A genealogical list
questions.correctAnswer: A chiasm highlighting God’s judgments and deliverances
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3’s poetic form employs chiasm, a literary structure that balances descriptions of divine judgment with salvation, emphasizing God’s sovereign control.

theological.title: Habakkuk Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Habakkuk Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 3:3, from which places does God come, and what is the reaction of the earth to His glory?
options: God came from Teman and the Holy One from mount Paran; the earth was full of His praise
God came from Babylon and the Holy One from Zion; the earth was silent
God came from Egypt and the Holy One from Sinai; the earth trembled
God came from Jerusalem and the Holy One from Carmel; the earth rejoiced
questions.correctAnswer: God came from Teman and the Holy One from mount Paran; the earth was full of His praise
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:3 states that God came from Teman and the Holy One from mount Paran, with His glory covering the heavens and the earth full of His praise. This reveals God's majestic presence and universal worship, consistent with Psalm 19:1 and Revelation 4:11.

questions.question: What imagery does Habakkuk 3:4 use to describe God's power and brightness?
options: His brightness was as the light; he had horns coming out of his hand; there was the hiding of his power
He was like a consuming fire with eyes of flame and wings of angels
He appeared as a cloud with thunder and lightning around Him
He was like a mighty warrior with a sword shining like the sun
questions.correctAnswer: His brightness was as the light; he had horns coming out of his hand; there was the hiding of his power
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:4 describes God's brightness like light and mentions horns coming out of His hand, symbolizing strength and authority, with the hiding of His power indicating His sovereign mystery. This aligns with Exodus 34:29-35 and Revelation 1:16.

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 3:5, what preceded God as He came?
options: Pestilence went before Him, and burning coals went forth at His feet
A great storm with thunder and lightning
A host of angels singing praises
A river of fire and brimstone
questions.correctAnswer: Pestilence went before Him, and burning coals went forth at His feet
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:5 states that pestilence went before God and burning coals went forth at His feet, emphasizing His righteous judgment and purifying power, consistent with Exodus 15:3 and Nahum 1:6.

questions.question: What does Habakkuk 3:6 say about God's relationship to the earth and nations?
options: He measured the earth, beheld and drove asunder the nations; everlasting mountains scattered; His ways are everlasting
He ignored the earth and nations, remaining distant and unapproachable
He created the earth but left nations to govern themselves
He judged only Israel and ignored other nations
questions.correctAnswer: He measured the earth, beheld and drove asunder the nations; everlasting mountains scattered; His ways are everlasting
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:6 portrays God as sovereign over the earth and nations, exercising control by scattering mountains and bowing hills, showing His eternal and unchanging ways, paralleling Psalm 46:2-3 and Isaiah 40:4-8.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 3:8, what question is asked regarding God's displeasure, and what is the imagery used to describe His mode of salvation?
options: Was the LORD displeased against the rivers? Did He ride upon horses and chariots of salvation?
Did the LORD ignore the mountains? Did He come as a lamb to save?
Was the LORD angry at the sun? Did He descend as a dove?
Did the LORD reject the seas? Did He send prophets to save?
questions.correctAnswer: Was the LORD displeased against the rivers? Did He ride upon horses and chariots of salvation?
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:8 questions if God's anger was against the rivers and describes Him riding on horses and chariots of salvation, symbolizing militant deliverance, consistent with Exodus 15:1-10 and 2 Kings 2:11.

questions.question: What is said about God's bow and His word in Habakkuk 3:9?
options: Thy bow was made quite naked, according to the oaths of the tribes, even thy word
Thy bow was broken, and thy word was silent
Thy bow was hidden, and thy word was forgotten
Thy bow was strong, but thy word was weak
questions.correctAnswer: Thy bow was made quite naked, according to the oaths of the tribes, even thy word
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:9 reveals God's bow is made naked, indicating readiness for battle, and His word is faithful to the oaths of the tribes, showing His reliability and covenant faithfulness, paralleling Psalm 89:34 and Isaiah 54:17.

questions.question: How do the mountains and the deep respond to God according to Habakkuk 3:10?
options: Mountains tremble; the deep utters his voice and lifts up his hands
Mountains stand firm; the deep is silent
Mountains rejoice; the deep flows gently
Mountains crumble; the deep is still
questions.correctAnswer: Mountains tremble; the deep utters his voice and lifts up his hands
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:10 depicts creation trembling and the deep roaring in response to God's presence, emphasizing His power over nature, consistent with Psalm 97:5 and Nahum 1:5.

questions.question: What miraculous event involving the sun and moon is described in Habakkuk 3:11?
options: The sun and moon stood still in their habitation at the light of God's arrows
The sun darkened and the moon turned to blood
The sun and moon moved rapidly across the sky
The sun and moon were hidden behind clouds
questions.correctAnswer: The sun and moon stood still in their habitation at the light of God's arrows
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:11 describes the sun and moon standing still, symbolizing divine control over cosmic order, echoing Joshua 10:12-13 and Psalm 74:16.

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 3:13, for whose salvation did God go forth and what was the result against the wicked?
options: For the salvation of His people with His anointed; He wounded the head of the wicked
For the salvation of the nations; He forgave the wicked
For the salvation of the temple; He protected the wicked
For the salvation of the kings; He crowned the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: For the salvation of His people with His anointed; He wounded the head of the wicked
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:13 states God went forth for His people's salvation with His anointed, striking the wicked’s head, showing divine deliverance and judgment, consistent with Psalm 2:2-9 and Isaiah 53:10.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 3:15, through what did God walk with His horses?
options: Through the sea and heap of great waters
Through the desert and wilderness
Through the mountains and valleys
Through the heavens and stars
questions.correctAnswer: Through the sea and heap of great waters
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:15 mentions God walking through the sea with His horses, illustrating His sovereign control over chaotic waters, resonating with Exodus 14:21-22 and Psalm 77:16-20.

questions.question: What physical and emotional reactions does the prophet describe in Habakkuk 3:16 when hearing God's voice?
options: My belly trembled; my lips quivered; rottenness entered into my bones; I trembled
I was filled with joy; my heart leapt; I sang praises
I was silent; my soul was calm; I rested
I was angry; my hands clenched; I shouted
questions.correctAnswer: My belly trembled; my lips quivered; rottenness entered into my bones; I trembled
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:16 describes deep fear and trembling at God's powerful voice, showing reverence and awe, akin to Job 4:14-16 and Isaiah 6:5.

questions.question: Despite devastating loss described in Habakkuk 3:17, what is the prophet’s response to God?
options: Yet I will rejoice in the LORD, I will joy in the God of my salvation
I will curse God and despair
I will seek revenge on my enemies
I will abandon my faith and flee
questions.correctAnswer: Yet I will rejoice in the LORD, I will joy in the God of my salvation
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:17-18 shows steadfast faith and joy in God even amid judgment and loss, reflecting trust consistent with Psalm 42:11 and James 1:2-4.

questions.question: What does Habakkuk 3:19 say about God’s strength and the believer’s ability to walk in difficult places?
options: The LORD God is my strength; He makes my feet like hinds' feet to walk upon high places
The LORD is weak; I stumble on low places
The LORD hides His strength; I fall often
The LORD is distant; I walk alone in darkness
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD God is my strength; He makes my feet like hinds' feet to walk upon high places
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:19 affirms God as the believer’s strength, enabling confident navigation of difficult paths, similar to Isaiah 40:31 and Psalm 18:33.

questions.question: Habakkuk 3:2 contains a plea for God to 'revive thy work in the midst of the years.' What theological truth does this express?
options: A request for God’s mercy and renewal amid judgment
A demand for immediate punishment without mercy
A declaration that God has abandoned His work
A denial of God’s control over time
questions.correctAnswer: A request for God’s mercy and renewal amid judgment
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 3:2 petitions God to remember mercy during wrath, highlighting God’s justice balanced with mercy, consistent with Exodus 34:6-7 and Lamentations 3:22-23.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'horns coming out of his hand' in Habakkuk 3:4 symbolize about God’s nature?
options: Power and authority to execute judgment
Weakness and vulnerability
Mercy without strength
Unpredictability and chaos
questions.correctAnswer: Power and authority to execute judgment
questions.explanation: The horns in Habakkuk 3:4 symbolize strength and power, common biblical imagery for authority (1 Samuel 2:1-10; Psalm 18:2; Revelation 5:6).
